item.title: Let the Info go!
item.description:
Let the Info go!

At the end of 2013 and 2014 I wrote blog posts on Occam's Corner (over at the Guardian) to list and briefly review the books I read in each of those years. I want to develop this practice into a good habit because it spurs me to read; and I hope it might also serve to flag up titles of interest to others.

item.title: Prehension: The Hand and the Emergence of Humanity
item.description:
Prehension: The Hand and the Emergence of Humanity

A potentially good book discussing the role of the human hand in evolution.

item.title: Great Anthropocene article
item.description:
Great Anthropocene article

A new analysis of the fossil record shows that a deep pattern in the structure of plant and animal communities remained the same for 300 million years. Then, 6,000 years ago, the pattern was disrupted--at about the same time that people started farming in North America and populations rose.

item.title: Browser's Gold Year End Award Article
item.description:
Browser's Gold Year End Award Article

Walter Pitts was used to being bullied. He'd been born into a tough family in Prohibition-era Detroit, where his father, a boiler-maker, had no trouble raising his fists to get his way. The neighborhood boys weren't much better. One afternoon in 1935, they chased him through the streets until he ducked into the local library to hide.
